reviewText: Spartan Assualt is truely a poor-man's Halo. An exceedingly bland story gives reason to the series of short missions avialable to you, each no more than ten or twenty minutes long. Shooting requires you hold down the fire button, an odd choice that ensures the player is always forced to forsee where the simply-minded enemies will go rather than shoot at where they already are. Mouse control is usually better than a controller because you recieve a reticle to help guide your shots. However, vehicles such as the scorpian tank and the ghost become incredibly difficult to control unless a controller is used, due to the translation from a fully 3D Halo environments to this isometric one, a potentially maddeding issue given that a least a few missions openly try to make you use these vehicles.\nThe average mission in Spartan Assualt is bland. The music is nice, but if you're a Halo fan you'll probably have heard it all before and, if you're like me, you might just find the music oddly out of place. Enemies are easily killed, so it really is a good idea to turn on a few skulls (alter the game to modify the difficulty). However, none of the skulls ever felt like a real solution, and even the skull that was directly related to increasing enemy difficulty" just made all the enemies more bullet-spongy.\nIn similer games
date: such as All Zombies Must Die and Nation Red
recommended: there is a tendency to throw large waves of easily killed bad-guys at you. In Spartan Assualt
hoursPlayed: there are never that many enemies
voteText: and increasing the difficulty just makes the same brain-dead enemies slightly tougher (more health). Given that Nation Red and All Zombies Must Die already exist
votesHelpful: I can't recommed this game.\nMost importantly: if you're hurting for more Halo on PC
votesTotal: like I was when I bought this
votesFunny: you'll just end up disapointed."

reviewText:
I stopped playing Halo after Reach for a few years until a friend of mine gave me a copy of Halo 4 which I thought was a pretty good modern Halo game though not without one or two faults. That same friend also gifted Halo Spartan Assault so a shout out goes to him for being a cool guy.

Halo Spartan Assault is a Top-Down or Twin Stick Shooter depending on what you call it and centres around a story about Spartan Palmer who appeared briefly during Halo 4 and a faceless Spartan Davis trying to stop a Covenant from destroying a planet that contains Forerunner artefacts capable of destroying planets. The story isn't all too interesting but the cutscenes are presented well in a simplistic manner so it is enough to keep most people at least somewhat interested.

Combat is nifty and you have several options of playing, I chose a controller but you're welcome to use a keyboard or touch screen layout. The game looks quite nice as you fight you will see Banshees and Hornets flying pass in the scenery which adds a layer of immersion. It reminds me of Halo Wars for the most part and also nearly everything feels like Halo which is a good accomplishment including gun audio, shields and enemy chatter. Except for the Drones, they make the sounds of the Alien Engineers which is a bit of a nitpick of mine.

The only real complaints other than two bull#%!$ levels is the lack of a Co-Op feature which these type of games begs for. The 360 and X1 versions have Co-Op but only online. Pure blasphemy. Also the levels were usually a bit too short (Though it was also for Windows Phone 8 so it sort of makes sense).

The presentation is nice, the story is a little boring and the combat is fun for the most part. But I would really only reccomend this to people who are big fans of Halo though the games works as its own story it won't keep non fans entertained. Still it's a nice little title to have and I give it a total score of 6/10. Go pick it up if you want to play something Halo related or enjoy Twin Stick Shooters.

reviewText:
This game is just another reason that proves Microsoft and 343 Industries are some of the most boneheaded video game makers on the planet!

reviewText:
This is a very good game to play casual. Quick to play and very fluid. Little replay value. Controls are easy to remember. Wish it had a multiplayer feature though. Honestly, it was ported off a mobile game. I wouldn't pay $5 for this. MAYBE 99 cetnts, like most moblie apps, but not $5. Also, I dislike the top-down style. Top-down isn't Halo. Halo is a first-person shooter. They went off the deep-end and drowned with this game.

6/10

2nd Edit: Switched from positive review to negative and added more detail after I played a bit more.

3rd Edit: These microtransactions are not ideal, and I wish you kept the upgrades you bought throughout the game. At least it's not real money.

reviewText:
If you play Lara Croft: Guardians of Light and swap out Lara for a Spartan and remove the climbing mechanic then you have Spartan Assault. While this game is clearly an ios port, and don't get me wrong I have nothing against that, it doesn't stand up to games of a similar play style hence the comparision to Guardians of Light. To put it simply this is a quick and boring game. Halo fans might get something out of it but I believe they will be in the minority. Games like this are meant to be played in 5 minute blasts while waiting for a bus and when you port games like that onto PC or consoles then they become quick and uninteresting because they're not designed to hold your attention for long periods. That being said I picked this up for about 50p so on that basis it's good.
Oh and it has some of the worst handling vehicles I have ever come across. It is mind numbingly bad and rage inducing when sucide grunts are storming your tank while you figure out what buttons you need to press this time in order to reverse.

It seems pretty short and could easily be beaten in a couple hours, but those couple of hours will be repetitious and infuriating. Oh wait I go play any other game and it's completely fine. This makes the movement absolutely annoying. With the hardest "skulls" enabled it's a breeze

reviewText:
Spartan Assault is a game that could be much better with very little effort:

The point is that you have no real reason to progress in the story, because:
- The story is completely uninteresting
- The levels all feel more or less the same
- All equipment is available since minute one and XP is only temporarily used to get an advantage.

The first two points could even stay the way they are honestly, but the player progression is the main problem here.
If my profile started at level one, I earned XP for each enemy and new mission beat and, with that XP, unlocked new weapons, armor abilities and passive upgrades with every level, the game would be extremely more fun to play because suddenly:

- You want to move on to the next level, because XP for beat missions would be 1. a fair amount and 2. unique.
- You want to get XP, because you want to upgrade everything and unlock new equipment.
- You want to upgrade everything, because it's simply a human obsession and it let's you replay completed missions with a different approach.
- You want to replay missions, because you want to get gold rating in every mission.
- You want to get gold rating in every mission because it gives you a special price (i.e. master chief armor) and so is the key to truly upgrading/completing everything.

Now we'd have a real arcade game going. Obviously more interesting levels would boost the whole thing even more but that would take more than a little artwork and programming.

So as of now, for 5$, Spartan Assault is a nice mini game for Halo-Fans, but if you aren't into the franchise you have no reason to pick it up.

reviewText: A cool game with an arcade type style, the game mechanics run smooth other then the Scorpian tanks which can be tricky to drive. Graphics are decent but the game play is kinda rededative and the details about the game arent as I was expecting, You don't actually make a Spartan or customize it, your only options for customising are your primary and secondary weapon along with any kinda booster and active item. I jumped into the game thinking I could actually make my own spartan which would be cool and join other players in pvp or pve. You just play tactics on different spartans who apperenlty exsisted. For the price its an alright game if you dont mind replaying the same missions that are easy-hard to beat depending on the amount of score you want at the end. I'd rather keep my money if I knew the game was at all like this.

reviewText: I was curious when I first saw this on Steam. Since it had the Halo name I knew I had to buy it and try it out, and for $4.99 there wasn't much to lose. For that price it is well worth it. The gameplay is solid and everything runs smoothly does what you tell it to do without any problems. There is also some variety in weapons and vehicles so don't expect to just use and assault rifle and walk around the whole time. The artwork and cutscenes are done well and it adds more lore to the Halo Universe so if you are interested in that this could be enticing. There are some other features like leaderboards that add replayability.\n\nWhile I doubt any new Halo games like Halo 5 or the rumored Halo 2 Anniversary will be on Steam hopefully in the future more Halo games will be available on the PC.

reviewText:
I immediately bought this game when I saw Halo in the title. Regretfully it's one of the worse purchases I've made.

It runs like junk on integrated GPU's (tested with HD4000 in 1080p) even though it's originally a game for smartphones. Just saying.. If you have a beefier GPU there will be no problems, but it shouldn't be necessary seeing the graphical fidelity of this title. Options menu lacks a bit, and the menus in general are quite annoying to navigate.

The most important thing for me though, since this game lacks in so many aspects: I'm not having fun, not having a laugh, not having a good time, not having a blast - not even remotely. The game itself is VERY dull and OBVIOUSLY catered towards casual smartphone gamers. It just lacks the soul of the entire franchise.

If you're looking for a PC game with PC values, avoid this. If you're looking for a mindnumbing waste of time, play Bejeweled instead, it's a lot more satisfying..

If you want an assesment of what this game has to offer from another, more positive viewpoint, I recommend you go watch TotalBiscuit's 'WTF is...' about the game: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uF1EA71nDA4

Educate yourselves before you toss your money at something. Don't make the same mistake I did.

reviewText:
Perhaps I am writing this because I am concerned - Perhaps I am writing this because I am angry. Any way you slice it, I am an unsatisfied customer. I have many games on steam which require a hefty and well maintained computer with respect to drivers. I play COD: Ghosts with high settings with out problem. Tomb Raider plays at a very high frame rate with settings on max. My computer is not the issue.

However, when I launch Halo: Spartan Assault, the game loads the splash screens, intro movie clips, then brings up a screen waiting for my input of choice. There, the game seems to lock up. I cannot select any option with the keyboard, mouse or Xbox 360 Controller.

I cannot get passed this screen, and therefore cannot even load the game. This is unacceptable.

I will be seeking how to get my money back. Save yours and skip this title.

reviewText:
I've been a huge Halo fan since the very first Combat Evolved on Xbox. This was mainly due to the epic story line. The game in itself, the back story, the history of your main character. Just the whole thing. I even guessed that the humans were or interacted with the forerunners in 2003 (not hard since 343 recognized our species). I've even read 2 of their many  books. I've owned and played every Halo game even the somewhat lame ones (Halo ODST & Halo Wars, not bad games just nothing compared to the rest). I was very happy to find Halo Spartan Assault on Steam.
If you're a fan like me then this game is a must have and since it's only $4.99 there's no real reason not to get it. I traded a game for it, a game I earned for free so even if you don't have money this is still obtainable.
I like top down shooters and this one runs incredibly smooth. The story takes place in between Halo 3 and 4 and focuses on the newer batch of Spartan II's. The game is a challenge if you try to obtain gold for every level and there are over 30 levels.
You play one of 2 Spartans back and forth as you complete missions. You only control your character but I think that's part of the fun (more like Halo 1-4 except not FPS). Board any vehicle and take your pick from nearly all of the UNST and Covenant weapons we've come to know in the previous games.
This isn't a long game and the replay value is moderate if you're a fan, but its a great arcade style of game play. Not complex and easy to learn.
If you're not a fan but you're looking to spend $5 on a decent game this is a good choice and it has trading cards that are selling in the Steam marketplace for a good amount at the moment compared to other cards.
If you're a fan then this game is a must have. Great visuals and more Covenant domination at the hands of the Spartan II's.
My only wish is that they made the game longer but for the price and the style of game that it is the length of the game isn't a surprise. Also even if they made the game with 100 levels I'd probably still want more... :)

column16: especially as the game itself is cheaper than the Official Soundtrack album (Which can be digitally downloaded from iTunes

column18: which I can actually recommend you buy
column21: does a surprisingly damn good job with the music! (I even consider it one of the game's biggest highlights
column22:
despite not being as notable as the works of Martin O'Donnell & Michael Salvatori)

My Review
Halo: Spartan Assault is a surprisingly competant designed-for-mobile top-down shooter which may be a very short-lived experience with not a great deal of replay value & even less narrative content
column23: it's certainly very gentle on the wallet & surprisingly translates the Halo experience into a new genre pretty well.\n\nIt controls well enough on Mouse & Keyboard (With fully rebindable keys aside from "Fire Weapon"
column24: "Throw Grenade" & "Pause" locked to the left & right mouse buttons & escape for odd reasons)
column25: but you certainly can't go wrong with a Gamepad. Just note that the weapons obey an automatic fire-rate with occasional fire-delay depending on their power or behaviour
column26: so don't be shocked if your Shotgun
column27: Pistol or Rocket Launcher doesn't fire a single shot on the click of a fire button like I was. It's part of the game's weapon design
column28: but it's not what I consider a very responsive one for those expecting to fire in single-shot.\n\nAnd to clarify
column29: there are none of the microtransactions as seen & negatively received on it's mobile release. The XP Points used to buy even more powerful weaponry & abilities for single mission use is earned based on in-game score
column30: which became an enjoyable resource management system for myself. Don't worry
column31: as long as you score big on your missions & spend wisely
column32: you won't have to do much to maintain your XP Points. Otherwise
column33: you won't need to do more than replay a mission you do well with more than twice to supplement your XP Points.\n\nIt's also worth noting that it unfortunately doesn't include the Co-op mode that was added to the console ports
column34: so you'll be shootin' solo.\n\nStory wise
column35: it's basically a Training Simulation recounting a battle that took place between Halo 3 & Halo 4's timelines
column36: where you as the player strive to earn your gold stars on the very short but numerous levels
column37: with Skulls aka Difficulty Modifiers to provide score multipliers & greater challenge and the previously mentioned arsenal of more powerful bought-for-single-mission-use weapons & abilities to customise your more varied mission-assigned loadouts. There's not really much more to it than that.\n\nAll-in-all
column38: if you need something cheap & cheerful and quick to install to kill some time or satisfy a need to shoot lots of bad guys
column39: you can't go very wrong with Halo: Spartan Assault! It's not a big recommendation
column40: but there's very little preventing me from doing so.\n\nSide Note: I wouldn't suggest purchasing it solely as a means of encouraging Microsoft Studios & 343 Industries to consider returning to porting the main-series Halo shooters onto PC. The enthusiastic result of Halo: Spartan Assault's debut on Steam has so far only lead to a follow-up
column41: "Halo: Spartan Strike" being made & coming to Steam on launch.\nA progressional result nonetheless
column42: but I would suggest a more specific method to advocate your desires to see such games as Halo 3 be ported to PC & distributed via Steam."

reviewText:
This is a good game. Pretty much the only Halo experience on PC.

There is a 6 sections each and 5 missions with in each section.
Each mission is straight forward and can be completed with in 5 minutes.
I finish the game in 4 hours, but the re-playablity is high.
For each mission you can turn on skulls, 7 to choose from; but can only
have 2 active during the mission.  You can also spend XP you earn in the
game to upgrade the mission loadout of weapons that are default.
For example, your primary is the assault rifle; you can spend your XP to
upgrade to 1) sniper rifle, 2) spartan rifle, 3) rocket laucher. You can
do the same for your secondary.
Each mission you are scored on each enemy that you kill, the medals
you earn, and for completing it as fast as possible. Giving you a bronze,
silver, or gold star for each mission.

Overall I enjoyed playing this game. The controls are tight and responsive.
There is a satisfaction in using each weapon. (All weapons have made it
over, mostly, even the focus rifle!  I mean the tickle rifle! Who doesn't love
that weapon, let's face it that gun is worthless. You spend all the energy
that gun has to offer and it's enough to kill 2 elites, and maybe 1 grunt.
Garbage! Pff! The nerve the coventant have. Whose bone headed cousin
invented that rifle only to have his more succsessful brother greenlight it
into production. Then come to find out the spartan's use it to play tag with.
I'd love to be a fly on the wall in that follow-up metting:
Head bossman tentical face - So how's the focus rifle out on the battlefield?
Ashamed brother - Oh! Ummmm, good. I ... I ...I mean it could do better.
Head bossman tentical face - Better? How so?
Ashamed brother - Well, for one it could start by killing the enemy.
Head bossman tentical face - What!?
Ashamed brother - Yes, well, it seemes that, cough, umm it appears that it
doesn't actually kill the enemy, actually.
Head bossman tentical face - Pff! Doesn't kill the enemy? Well then what
does it do?
Ashamed brother - It, uh, it, swallows pride, it tickles the enemy.
Head bossman tentical face - You must be joking. Great scot! So you're
telling me that the coventant has a weapon
that just tickles the enemy?
Ashamed brother - Yes. Yes we do.
Head bossman tentical face - Does it at least tickle the enemy to death?
Ashamed brother - Yes! Wait, no. No, doesn't do that. Would be nice.
Head bossman tentical face - So then what's our plan of action?
Ashamed brother - I believe to keep, using, the weapon?
Head bossman tentical face - Well, I doubt that would make us lose the war.
Next order of business. Can someone please
inform the grunts that, yes, while we all have a
laugh when they put a plasma grenade in the
toilet to scare everyone it's starting to stink up
the place and it's causing the flood.)

In conclusion, very nice game.

reviewText:
Bottom Line:
> 8/10 for Games overall. Easy 10/10 for what-it-is (Mobile Port). Very fun. Seriously hope Vanguard puts out another full-length one!
> Didn't quite scratch my 'FPS' itch (since it's a TDS), but it came surprisingly close... still haven't had this much fun with Halo since CE (#‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•).
> This game is a steal at $5. At &1.49... it's a Goldman-Sachs.

Summary:
> Halo-themed top-down shooter, featuring Spt. Palmer from Halo 4, and all the usual suspects for baddies.
> 30 short, satisfying missions.
> Mouse to aim, WASD to move. ALL typical halo weapons up to Reach, 'Nades, Melee. Vehicles. Loadouts. Armor abilities. Medals n' stuff.

Thoughts:
> 60 minutes in, I realized that I had happily fallen into the exact same subconscious shoot-nade-melee dance that I deveoped playing Halo CE all those years ago :]
> Combat makes emptying your Assault rifle clip FUN like not since Halo 3/CE. Good pace, well-balanced... even with every combination of skulls!
> Was made with love: good original music / cinematics / world & level design / ambiance.
> Attention given to TINY game details... you'll see when you play.
> AI is SOLID - like the best of CE and 3 put together, with EVEN fewer bugs.
> Marines are actually durable and useful.
> Only saw three small bugs the whole game.

Graphics:
To me, there are two types of People when it comes to Graphics:
A] The Fetishists"

reviewText:
I got this game for a buck fifty, and that's about what it's worth.  It's a top down shooter version of Halo, but with no real story.  No plot, no persistent upgrades (there's a handful of generic upgrades you can buy PER MISSION, but you'll almost never be able to afford them), no RPG or rogue elements (didn't expect any, but the story is supposed to make up for that in action games).  Missions are 1-10 minutes long at most, unless you're REALLY horrible.

Essentially, you take a 1st person shooter, strip out aiming, crouching, running, cover, and just about all other skill related aspects, but don't replace them with RPG/rogue elements like you might normally see in similar top down games.  You really aren't left with much.

Started getting bored by the lack of...ANY substance at about hour 1, but for $1.50 I guess I expect that.

The sad part is that they have to be losing money on this game at even full price of $5.00, and it COULD have been a much better game with just a little work.  Add some persistent stats/upgrades and you'd have a $10 game at least, and it wouldn't have taken much work.  Meh.

Recommended ONLY on sale.  Don't buy if it's not on sale.

reviewText: $5 for this game is a steal. I paid a sale price of $1.69, and I feel like I not only stole the game, but I also shot an employee during the robbery. They could have listed the game at $20 and it would have been well worth the money.\n\nThis is one well-made and freaking fun game. People bash it because it's a Halo game that's not first-person, but those people are idiots. The gameplay is a ton of fun, the visuals and music are incredible, and overall it's just a really well-polished game. The campaign isn't all that long, but there are a lot of different optional things to do, so completion will take considerably longer than just playing through the game. And if you really do feel it's too short, there's a sequel in the works that should be coming out within the next few months. Really, though, for a $5 game, you get far more than your money's worth.

reviewText:
I've been a huge Halo fan since the very first Combat Evolved on Xbox. This was mainly due to the epic story line. The game in itself, the back story, the history of your main character. Just the whole thing. I even guessed that the humans were or interacted with the forerunners in 2003 (not hard since 343 recognized our species). I've even read 2 of their many  books. I've owned and played every Halo game even the somewhat lame ones (Halo ODST & Halo Wars, not bad games just nothing compared to the rest). I was very happy to find Halo Spartan Assault on Steam.
If you're a fan like me then this game is a must have and since it's only $4.99 there's no real reason not to get it. I traded a game for it, a game I earned for free so even if you don't have money this is still obtainable.
I like top down shooters and this one runs incredibly smooth. The story takes place in between Halo 3 and 4 and focuses on the newer batch of Spartan II's. The game is a challenge if you try to obtain gold for every level and there are over 30 levels.
You play one of 2 Spartans back and forth as you complete missions. You only control your character but I think that's part of the fun (more like Halo 1-4 except not FPS). Board any vehicle and take your pick from nearly all of the UNST and Covenant weapons we've come to know in the previous games.
This isn't a long game and the replay value is moderate if you're a fan, but its a great arcade style of game play. Not complex and easy to learn.
If you're not a fan but you're looking to spend $5 on a decent game this is a good choice and it has trading cards that are selling in the Steam marketplace for a good amount at the moment compared to other cards.
If you're a fan then this game is a must have. Great visuals and more Covenant domination at the hands of the Spartan II's.
My only wish is that they made the game longer but for the price and the style of game that it is the length of the game isn't a surprise. Also even if they made the game with 100 levels I'd probably still want more... :)

column18: and to Microsoft for getting the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of the way for once and allowing this thing to be born.\n> Though doubtful

reviewText:
I got this game for a buck fifty, and that's about what it's worth.  It's a top down shooter version of Halo, but with no real story.  No plot, no persistent upgrades (there's a handful of generic upgrades you can buy PER MISSION, but you'll almost never be able to afford them), no RPG or rogue elements (didn't expect any, but the story is supposed to make up for that in action games).  Missions are 1-10 minutes long at most, unless you're REALLY horrible.

Essentially, you take a 1st person shooter, strip out aiming, crouching, running, cover, and just about all other skill related aspects, but don't replace them with RPG/rogue elements like you might normally see in similar top down games.  You really aren't left with much.

Started getting bored by the lack of...ANY substance at about hour 1, but for $1.50 I guess I expect that.

The sad part is that they have to be losing money on this game at even full price of $5.00, and it COULD have been a much better game with just a little work.  Add some persistent stats/upgrades and you'd have a $10 game at least, and it wouldn't have taken much work.  Meh.

Recommended ONLY on sale.  Don't buy if it's not on sale.

reviewText:
I have a slight feeling that this is Microsoft's attempt at seeing how well a PC release of a Halo game goes. Well, for me, it went great.

For a top-down shooter, it's a really great game. It may be a tad bit easy, but have there been ANY hard top-down shooters (Besides Space Rangers. I loved it.)

Alright, so, let's review the plot first, shall we?

The events occur around 2554 (UNSC military calendar). You are placed in the boots of either Spartan Edward Davis or Spartan Sarah Palmer, depending on the mission. Draetheus V and its moon, X50, are under attack by Covenant cultists, led by Parg Vol and Merg Vol. They seek a Forerunner device on the planet, but encounter fierce UNSC resistance. The battle drags on, and the UNSC utilizes some weapons and vehicles that the Covenant haven't seen yet, or for a long time. In the end, the UNSC wins the bloody battle, but at the cost of hundreds of brave Marines and Spartan Edward Davis.

In the beginning of each mission, you get to choose your loadout, albeit, at a cost. If you had exceptional records in your previous mission, you can access either a rocket launcher, the one-shot-wonder (Sniper Rifle) or the Spartan Laser. You can also activate skulls for additional difficulty and increased rewards.

The only downside of the game is that it's a top-down shooter, and not a full-scale FPS or a TPS. Also, the vehicle controls can be very difficult and/or sluggish at times and it will be brutal to maneuver out of a Mega Cannon's firing lane, especially in narrow corridors.

I'd recommend this game to anyone who considers himself a true Halo fan. It's not a massive Halo game, or Halo 4 on PC, but it's definitely something. Let's hope Microsoft finally understands the value of moving Halo to the PC.

My Review
Halo: Spartan Assault is a surprisingly competant designed-for-mobile top-down shooter which may be a very short-lived experience with not a great deal of replay value & even less narrative content
column23: it's certainly very gentle on the wallet & surprisingly translates the Halo experience into a new genre pretty well.\n\nIt controls well enough on Mouse & Keyboard (With fully rebindable keys aside from "Fire Weapon"
column24: "Throw Grenade" & "Pause" locked to the left & right mouse buttons & escape for odd reasons)
column25: but you certainly can't go wrong with a Gamepad. Just note that the weapons obey an automatic fire-rate with occasional fire-delay depending on their power or behaviour
column26: so don't be shocked if your Shotgun
column27: Pistol or Rocket Launcher doesn't fire a single shot on the click of a fire button like I was. It's part of the game's weapon design
column28: but it's not what I consider a very responsive one for those expecting to fire in single-shot.\n\nAnd to clarify
column29: there are none of the microtransactions as seen & negatively received on it's mobile release. The XP Points used to buy even more powerful weaponry & abilities for single mission use is earned based on in-game score
column30: which became an enjoyable resource management system for myself. Don't worry
column31: as long as you score big on your missions & spend wisely
column32: you won't have to do much to maintain your XP Points. Otherwise
column33: you won't need to do more than replay a mission you do well with more than twice to supplement your XP Points.\n\nIt's also worth noting that it unfortunately doesn't include the Co-op mode that was added to the console ports
column34: so you'll be shootin' solo.\n\nStory wise
column35: it's basically a Training Simulation recounting a battle that took place between Halo 3 & Halo 4's timelines
column36: where you as the player strive to earn your gold stars on the very short but numerous levels
column37: with Skulls aka Difficulty Modifiers to provide score multipliers & greater challenge and the previously mentioned arsenal of more powerful bought-for-single-mission-use weapons & abilities to customise your more varied mission-assigned loadouts. There's not really much more to it than that.\n\nAll-in-all
column38: if you need something cheap & cheerful and quick to install to kill some time or satisfy a need to shoot lots of bad guys
column39: you can't go very wrong with Halo: Spartan Assault! It's not a big recommendation
column40: but there's very little preventing me from doing so.\n\nSide Note: I wouldn't suggest purchasing it solely as a means of encouraging Microsoft Studios & 343 Industries to consider returning to porting the main-series Halo shooters onto PC. The enthusiastic result of Halo: Spartan Assault's debut on Steam has so far only lead to a follow-up
column41: "Halo: Spartan Strike" being made & coming to Steam on launch.\nA progressional result nonetheless
column42: but I would suggest a more specific method to advocate your desires to see such games as Halo 3 be ported to PC & distributed via Steam."

reviewText: It's a decently fun game, and has great playthrough factor the first time, but nearly 0 replay factor. Unless you're a hardcore completionist, you're going to run out of things to do. Every level has stars for how well you did, but they don't have any real impact on the game. It also features weekly and daily challenges to do, but again they don't have any real impact. It would have been better if we could have different armour and weapon unlocks, allowing us to change our Spartan's look or start levels with different equipment combos. I understand we're supposed to be playing to specific Spartans, but honestly who cares? I'd still rather be able to change the look of my armour than worry about sticking to cannon. It's the same thing that's bugged me in nearly every Halo game except for one. (Sorry, but I've never found the MC's look all that special.)\nAlso, something else that's disconcerning is the lack of multiplayer. This game would have a much greater replay factor if I could play it with friends instead of always playing solo. The fact that it doesn't have any makes you wonder why they didn't think to do it.\nIn the end, I would recommend this game for a fun, one-time playthrough, but the lack of options, customization, and multiplayer leads me to not fully recommend it.

reviewText: 10/10 - If you are any fan of the Halo franchise you should look into this game. It takes many characters, weapons, and vehicles from other Halo games. Halo: Spartan Assault is a top-down shooter making it similar to Halo Wars on Xbox 360. The controls are very simple and are not difficult to remember like some games. The story isn't very long but you can always go back with different weapons, armor abilities, etc. As a Steam Trading Card user I only buy games with trading cards available, hence why I purchased this game. I have a three year old trash laptop and it can run this game which I was impressed by. For $4.99 this game is well worth the money!

reviewText: AMAZING! I am not sure if it is amazing because it is actually amazing or because my personal bias love for Halo made it amazing! Halo: Spartan Assault was a great and amazing game that, despite having very few cutscenes, was a great story! I wish I owned an X-Box to play Halo Reach and 4 :( Despite the game took me only about 3 hours to beat, it was so fun! And really hard to O_O No checkpoints, at all. You die, you restart the level! I wish more Halo games were on PC because 1, 2 and Spartan Assault :( If you love Halo or over the top shooters, pick up Halo: Spartan Assault! :D <3

reviewText:
Very disappointing two stick shooter.  Story?  What story? Music? Yawnsville. Voice acting?  Well there's some guy reciting lines with a monotonous lack of enthusiasm.

Couple that with bottomless-clip-shoot-until-the-ammo-runs-out, zero imagination, and a buttload of mouse lag that makes the game downright infuriating at times (not that there was any fun to be ruined while playing), I'd have to say this is the worst $1.50 I've ever spent.

I should have bought a Kit-Kat bar.

reviewText:
A fun little top down shooter set in the Halo Universe.
Its a fun game at a good price. The levels are fun filled and enjoyable. Although the driving seems a bit wonky when your in a tank and the ai can be stupid at times.

The game comes with achievements, and a point leadeboard system which adds some replayability.

If you're a halo fan then you should  give this game a try.
7/10.

reviewText:
Everything you need to know about Halo: Spartan Assault in a One Minute video.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Syq5dK3fTEs
For those who'd rather read than watch:
Not a bad purchase at all and probably the best mobile-PC port out there at the moment, save for an irritating EXP system (think currency and you're not far off), dodgy keyboard controls for vehicles and an inexplicable screen format with two corners cut off. It feels and sounds like a proper HALO game, though, and has some nice looking cutscenes.  Would recommend at sale price.
